Description:
Dictionary Entry: 999

Pronunciation: nine-nine-nine

Alternate Spellings: None

Definition:
1. Adjective:
   a. Used to describe something that is highly intense, extreme, or excessive in nature.
   b. Used to express a state of complete exhaustion, often after an arduous or physically demanding activity.

2. Interjection:
   a. Used to indicate surprise, shock, or disbelief.

Usage:
1. Adjective:
   a. This durian is 999 spicy! I can't handle the heat!
   b. After playing soccer for two hours straight, I am feeling 999 tired.

2. Interjection:
   a. 999! You won the lottery? That's incredible!
   b. 999! I can't believe you managed to finish the entire buffet by yourself!

Note: '999' is a commonly used term in Singlish and originates from the Singapore civil defense emergency hotline number, which is 999. Over time, Singaporeans have adapted this number to express extreme intensity or exhaustion, as well as to convey surprise or disbelief in certain situations.

Entry: 007
Pronunciation: "Double-Oh-Seven"

Definition: 
007 is a common shorthand in Singlish for a person who is seen as sophisticated, charming, or suave. The term was popularized by the British spy character James Bond who has a license to kill and is often seen as cool, calm, and collected. It is commonly used to describe someone who is effortlessly smooth and confident, especially in romantic situations.

Example:
"Wow, look at him talking to all those girls like it's nothing. He thinks he's 007 or something."

Note:
The term is usually used in a lighthearted or humorous manner and should not be taken too seriously. It is not a positive label to be given to someone, as it can also suggest arrogance or an overly confident attitude.
Description(Final): 007 is a common shorthand in Singlish for a person who is seen as sophisticated, charming, or suave. The term was popularized by the British spy character James Bond who has a license to kill and is often seen as cool, calm, and collected. It is commonly used to describe someone who is effortlessly smooth and confident, especially in romantic situations.

Word: 1.5
Part of Speech: Adjective
Pronunciation: wuhn-point-faiv

Definition:
- Used to describe something that is not quite good enough or satisfactory.
- Also used to describe something that is mediocre or average.
- Derived from the numerical value 1.5 which is in between a passing grade of 2.0 and failing grade of 1.0.

Example:
"Your chicken rice is not bad lah, but it's still 1.5 only compared to the one at the hawker centre." 

Note: 'lah' is a common Singlish particle used for emphasis.

11B

Pronunciation: /ˈɛlɛvən bi:/

Alternate spellings: Nil

Definition:
1. (Noun) A term used in Singapore to refer to the pink identification card issued by the Ministry of Defense (MINDEF) to male citizens and permanent residents upon completion of their mandatory National Service (NS). The 11B card serves as proof and recognition of an individual's completion of NS obligations and is required to be carried at all times for identification purposes.

Example:
"Hey bro, make sure to bring your 11B when we go out later, just in case we get stopped for any military checks."

Usage note:
The term '11B' is derived from the combination of two components: '11' represents the year an individual enlisted for NS (e.g., 11 for enlistees in 2011), and 'B' denotes the blood group of the individual. However, the blood group is no longer printed on the card itself since 2004. The 11B is a significant piece of identification for NSmen (National Service men) and is recognized as a symbol of a Singaporean's commitment and duty towards the nation.

Entry: 13th Month

Pronunciation: \ˌthərd ˈmən(t)th\n
Alternate Spelling: 13th Mth

Definition:
The term "13th month" is a colloquial expression commonly used in Singlish to refer to an additional month's salary or bonus received by employees in addition to their regular monthly pay. This bonus typically corresponds to one month's worth of salary and is often given out during the festive season, usually in December, as a token of appreciation for the employee's hard work throughout the year.

Example:
"Lucky lah, this year my boss gave us 13th month bonus! Extra money for Christmas shopping!"

Note:
The term "13th month" is used in a non-literal sense, as it does not literally refer to a thirteenth month added to the calendar. It is important to remember that this expression is specific to Singapore and may not be widely understood outside of the local context.

Description:
Title: AAAA

Part of Speech: Interjection

Pronunciation: [ah-ah-ah-ah]

Description:
ACS (noun) 

Pronunciation: /ˈeɪ.si.ɛs/ 

Alternate spellings: Anglo-Chinese School

Definition:
ACS, short for Anglo-Chinese School, is a prestigious and well-established educational institution in Singapore. The term is commonly used to refer to any of the various schools affiliated with the ACS brand, including ACS (Barker Road), ACS (Independent), ACS (Primary), and ACS (International) among others. ACS schools are known for their rich history, academic excellence, and strong emphasis on character development and values-based education. These schools are highly regarded for their holistic approach to education, nurturing students intellectually, physically, socially, and morally. ACS schools are recognized for their strong sporting teams, performing arts programs, and community involvement.

Example:
- "My son just got accepted into ACS (Primary)! We're so proud of him."
- "Are you an ACS alumni? That's awesome!"
- "ACS schools are known for producing well-rounded individuals with strong leadership skills."

Note:
In Singlish, ACS is commonly used as a shorthand term to refer to any of the ACS-affiliated schools, highlighting the cultural familiarity with these prestigious institutions.

Description:
Dictionary entry:

Act blur 

Pronunciation: /akt bler/

Definition: To pretend to be unaware of something or to feign ignorance in order to avoid responsibility, confrontation or to evade answering questions.

Example: "When the teacher asked who left their books on the floor, John acted blur and pretended he didn't hear the question."

Origin: The term 'act blur' is a slang phrase commonly used in Singapore and Malaysia. It is a combination of two English words 'act' meaning to pretend and 'blur' meaning to be unclear or not understanding something. The term is also influenced by the Singlish phrase 'blur like sotong' which means being oblivious or confused.

Usage: The phrase 'act blur' is frequently used in informal settings to describe someone who is trying to avoid responsibility or to get away from answering a difficult question. It is also commonly used in workplace or school settings when one wishes to avoid getting into trouble. However, the phrase can also have negative connotations and may be seen as a form of dishonesty.

Description:
Aduh

Pronunciation: ah-doo

Alternate spellings: Ahduh, adoh

Definition:
Aduh is an interjection commonly used in Singlish to express surprise, frustration, pain, or exasperation. It is versatile and can be used in various situations to convey different emotions. The intensity and tone with which it is uttered can vary depending on the context.

Example:

1. "Aduh, I missed the bus again!"
   (expressing frustration and disappointment)

2. "Aduh! That hurt!"
   (expressing pain or surprise)

3. "Aduh, how can you say that?"
   (expressing disbelief or exasperation)

4. "Aduh, why so hot lah!"
   (expressing the feeling of discomfort)

Usage notes:
- Aduh is often elongated for emphasis, like "Adoooooh!" or "Aduuuuh!"
- This exclamation is commonly heard and used in Singapore and among the local ethnic communities.
- Aduh is similar to the English interjections "oh no," "ouch," or "geeze."

Related terms:
- Aiyah: an interjection expressing resignation or mild annoyance
- Alamak: an interjection expressing surprise or disappointment

Note: Singlish, short for Singaporean English, refers to the unique creole language spoken in Singapore, which incorporates elements of English, Mandarin Chinese, Malay, Tamil, and various Chinese dialects.
Description(Final): An expression to express pain like 'ouch'
Example(Final): 1. Aduh! So pain my head!

Sure, here's the dictionary entry for 'agak':

Word: Agak (ah-gahk)
Description: Agak is a term commonly used in Singlish that means 'estimate' or 'guess'. It can be used in a variety of situations, such as when trying to figure out a price or time frame, or when making an approximation based on limited information.

Example:
- "Eh, how much you think this shirt cost ah?" "Agak only, maybe around $20-$30?"
- "What time you think the bus come ah?" "Agak la, maybe in 10-15 minutes."

Notes:
- Agak is often used in combination with other Singlish terms, such as 'agak-agak' (roughly estimating) or 'agak-ed' (already estimated).
- The pronunciation of 'agak' is similar to the English word 'ah' followed by the word 'gahk'.
Description(Final): Agak is a term commonly used in Singlish that means 'estimate' or 'guess'. It can be used in a variety of situations, such as when trying to figure out a price or time frame, or when making an approximation based on limited information. Agak is often used in combination with other Singlish terms, such as 'agak-agak' (roughly estimating) or 'agak-ed' (already estimated).\n- The pronunciation of 'agak' is similar to the English word 'ah' followed by the word 'gahk'.
Example(Final):
1. Eh, how much you think this shirt cost ah?
2. Agak only, maybe around $20-$30?
3. What time you think the bus come ah?
4. Agak la, maybe in 10-15 minutes.

Description:
Entry: Agak Agak

Pronunciation: uh-guhk uh-guhk

Alternate spellings: Agar Agar, Ahgo Ahgo

Definition:
Agak agak is a Singlish phrase that derives its roots from the Malay language. It is typically used to express a rough estimation or a guess. The phrase can be translated to mean "roughly" or "approximately" in English. It is commonly employed in everyday conversations to describe a haphazard estimation of measurements, time, or quantities when precise information is not available.

Example usages:
1. "How long will it take to reach the mall?" 
   "Agak agak, about 20 minutes by car."

2. "Can you estimate the weight of this package?"
   "I'd say agak agak around 3 kilograms."

3. "What time will the meeting start?"
   "Agak agak, maybe around 2:30 pm."

The phrase 'agak agak' is widely used in Singapore and is often considered an essential part of Singlish dialect. It adds a casual and relaxed tone to conversations, allowing individuals to provide a rough estimate without needing to be overly precise.
Description(Final): Redirect to agak

Description:
ah

Definition: 

Ah is an interjection commonly used in Singlish to express various emotions or to seek agreement, clarification, or affirmation. It can be translated to English as "yes," "I see," "okay," or "oh" depending on the context. Ah is typically used at the end of a sentence or as a standalone utterance. Its exact meaning and interpretation can vary based on tone and context.

Alternate Spellings: 

There are no widely accepted alternate spellings for ah. However, it may be spelled as "arh" or "aah" to emphasize different tones of expression.

Example Usage:

1. Expressing agreement:
   - "Wah, this durian is very tasty, ah!"
   - "You want to go out for dinner? Ah, can!"

2. Seeking confirmation:
   - "Tomorrow's meeting is at 3 p.m., ah?"
   - "The concert is at 7 p.m., ah?"

3. Indicating understanding:
   - "I need to go to the bank first, ah."
   - "You mean I have to study the whole week, ah?"

4. Expressing surprise or realization:
   - "Wah, this car is so expensive, ah!"
   - "You didn't tell me you were going on vacation, ah?"

Notes:

Ah is a versatile interjection used extensively in Singlish. Its proper interpretation often relies on context, tone, and body language. It adds flavor and expressiveness to conversations and is an integral part of the Singlish linguistic style.
Description(Final):
Ah is an ubiquitous word in Singlish that serves multiple purposes. 
1) Ah is used in nicknames when addressing people. This ah is usually pronounced with a mid level tone. (tone 3)
2) Ah is also a particle. With a rising tone, ah is used with imperatives to soften commands and reduce distance and can help to promote a reply when used with questions. (tone 2)
3) The rising tone ah also serves as a topic marker. (tone 2)
4) Themid tone ah marks a question that is looking for confirmation from the hearer. (tone 3)
Example(Final):
1. Ah3 Beng, how are you?
2. Don't play play ah2! translation: Don't mess around
3. This boy ah2, never hand in homework one.
4. You want me to help ah3?

Description:
Title: Ah Beng

Pronunciation: Ah-beng

Alternate Spellings: ABeng, Ah Ben

Definition:
Ah Beng is a commonly used slang term in Singapore to refer to a stereotypical young Chinese man who displays distinctive characteristics such as flashy fashion sense, gelled and spiked hair, preference for loud and ostentatious accessories, and a tendency to engage in rowdy or boisterous behavior. The term often carries a humorous or light-hearted tone, and is sometimes used affectionately to refer to friends with similar traits, although it can also be used in a derogatory manner.

Example:
Ah Beng came to the party wearing his signature loud, neon-colored shirt and gold chains.

Origin:
The term "Ah Beng" is believed to have originated from the Chinese Hokkien dialect, with "Ah" being a common prefix used in Singaporean Chinese slang to address or refer to someone, and "Beng" being a Hokkien term for "gangster" or someone who exhibits rebellious, uncouth behavior.

Usage:
1. "Eh, where all the Ah Bengs hang out one ah?"
2. "Don't be such an Ah Beng lah! Put away those flashy accessories."

Note:
While the term "Ah Beng" is primarily used to describe young Chinese men, it is worth noting that similar stereotypes exist across different ethnicities in Singapore, such as "Ah Lian" (for young Chinese women) or "Ah Seng" (for young Malay men).
Description(Final): A common Chinese name in Singapore used to refer to a young Chinese man in Singapore, associated with a stereotype of having little education or sophistication and operating within secret societies and street gangs.
Example(Final): "He just dyed his hair blonde. I didn't want to tell him, but he kind of looks like an ah beng now"

Description:
Ah boy

Pronunciation: /ɑː bɔɪ/

Alternate spellings: Ah boi, Ahbuay

Definition:
Ah boy is a common term used in Singlish to refer to a young boy or a young man. It is often used affectionately and is commonly heard in daily conversations amongst Singaporeans. The term is a fusion of the Chinese word "ah" (meaning "little" or "hey") and the English word "boy". 

Example:
1. "Eh, see that ah boy, so cheeky one!"
2. "Ah boy, go buy some kopi for me, please."

Usage notes:
- The term "ah boy" can be used irrespective of the age of the person being referred to. It can refer to a boy or young man from childhood to early adulthood.

Description:
Ah Long

Pronunciation: ah long

Alternate spellings: Ah Beng, Ah Long, Ah Beng Long

Definition:
Ah Long is a term used in Singlish to refer to an illegal moneylender or loan shark. It is derived from the Hokkien dialect, with "Ah" being a common prefix used to address someone, and "Long" meaning a dragon. Together, the term suggests that these moneylenders are often ruthless and possess an intimidating presence, just like a dragon. Ah Longs typically operate through illegal channels, offering high-interest loans to individuals who are in need of immediate cash. They generally target vulnerable borrowers, often using intimidation tactics or violence to enforce repayment.

Example:
1. "I heard he borrowed money from an Ah Long to pay off his gambling debts."
2. "Be careful when dealing with Ah Longs, they charge exorbitant interest rates and can be dangerous."

Note: The activities of Ah Longs are illegal and should be reported to the relevant authorities. It is recommended to seek alternative legal sources of finance in order to avoid getting involved with Ah Longs.
Description(Final): Ah long is a term used in Singapore to refer to loan sharks. They are typically unlicensed moneylenders who charge very high interest rates and use harassment, intimidation, and violence to collect payments from borrowers who are unable to pay off their debts.
Example(Final): 1. I heard he borrowed money from an Ah Long to pay off his gambling debts.

Ah long san (pronounced "ah-lung sahn") refers to the debt collector who works for the loan shark. These individuals are responsible for collecting payments from borrowers and may use aggressive tactics to do so.

AK is short for 'Auntie-Killer', a term that is commonly used in colloquial Singaporean English, also known as Singlish. The term is typically used to refer to trendy young men who are successful at attracting and impressing older women - generally those who are referred to as "aunties" in Singapore. The term is often used in a playful, admiring manner among friends, but can also be used to tease someone who is seen as trying too hard to impress older women.

Description:
Sure, here's a dictionary entry for 'akshen aje':

Word: Akshen Aje
Pronunciation: /ak-shen aj/

Definition: 'Akshen aje' is a Singlish phrase that means to do something without any particular reason or purpose, or to do something just for the sake of doing it. It can also imply a lack of seriousness or commitment towards a task or action. The phrase derives from the English words 'action' and 'only', with the Singlish habit of dropping '-tion' endings and replacing them with '-je'.

Examples:
1. "Why did you buy that shirt? Akshen aje only ah?"
Translation: Why did you buy that shirt? Was it just for the sake of buying something?

2. "I'm just going to walk around the mall, akshen aje."
Translation: I'm going to walk around the mall without any particular purpose or agenda.

3. "Don't do things akshen aje-ly lah. You need to focus!"
Translation: Don't do things without any purpose or commitment. You need to focus!

Note: 'Akshen aje' is a casual and colloquial phrase that is typically used in informal settings or conversations with friends and family.

Alah (ah-lah)

Pronunciation: /ɑːlɑː/ or /ɑːlə/

Alternate spellings: Ah lah

Definition:
Alah is a frequently used interjection in the Singlish language, derived from the Malay word "Allah," which means God. It is an expression used to display a range of emotions such as surprise, disappointment, or frustration. The versatility of "alah" allows it to be used in various contexts with different meanings, making it a fundamental element of Singlish.

Example:
1. Surprise: "Alah! You won the lottery? Wah, so lucky!"
2. Disappointment: "I thought my food delivery was here, but it was just a text message. Alah."
3. Frustration: "Alah, the bus left just as I reached the bus stop!"

Cultural Significance:
"Alah" reflects the multicultural influences in Singapore, with its origin in Malay. It has become an integral part of Singlish, bridging cultural divides and unifying people from different backgrounds. The distinctiveness and familiarity of "alah" contribute to its widespread usage and recognition among Singaporeans.

Usage Notes:
1. "Alah" can be used alone as an interjection or combined with other words to form phrases.
2. In informal settings, "alah" can also be elongated to "alaahhhh" for added emphasis or exaggeration.
3. It is important to note that this interjection, while accepted and widely used in Singapore, may not be suitable for formal contexts.

Note: Singlish is a blend of English, Malay, Chinese, Tamil, and other local dialects, which shapes the linguistic landscape of Singapore.
Description(Final): An expression to show concern, frustration, dismay or surprise
Example(Final): 1. Alah! Your shirt all dirty now!

Description:
alamak (ə-lə-mak) [Alternate spelling: alamak]

Definition:
Alamak is an exclamation widely used in Singlish, a colloquial form of English widely spoken in Singapore. It is typically employed to express shock, surprise, frustration, or disappointment. This versatile term can be used in a myriad of situations and is often accompanied by gestures or facial expressions to enhance its effect.

Pronunciation: 
ə-lə-mak

Examples:
1. "Alamak, I forgot to bring my umbrella! Now I'll get soaked in this rain."
2. "You accidentally deleted all the files? Alamak, how can you make such a mistake?"
3. "Alamak, the queue is so long! We might not be able to get a table."

Usage Notes:
- Alamak is known for its ability to convey a wide range of emotions depending on the context and tone of voice.
- This term is often used as a standalone exclamation or integrated within sentences to add emphasis.
- It can be spoken with varying tones and elongated vowels to intensify its impact.
- In informal text messages or online conversations, 'alamak' may be spelled as 'alamk' or 'alamok' to mimic its pronunciation.

Origin:
The word 'alamak' is influenced by Malay language and culture. It is a loanword derived from the Malay expression 'ala, mak,' which loosely translates to "oh no, mother." Over time, it has become highly integrated into the Singaporean lexicon and is now a common feature of Singlish.

Note: The Singaporean government promotes the use of Standard English in formal settings, although Singlish remains widely spoken and cherished as part of the country's cultural identity.

It is typically employed to express shock, surprise, frustration, or disappointment. This versatile term can be used in a myriad of situations and is often accompanied by gestures or facial expressions to enhance its effect.
Example(Final): 1. Alamak! I forgot my keys at home again.

Title: Already

Word Type: Adverb

Pronunciation: /ɔːlˈrɛdi/ 

Alternate Spellings: Ahl-ready, Oredi, O'ledi

Definition:
'Already' is a versatile and commonly used adverb in Singlish. It is borrowed from the English language but has adapted a distinct meaning and usage in Singaporean English. It is used to convey the notion of completed action or the fact that something has occurred earlier than expected.

Example Sentences:
1. "I told you already, no need to remind me again." 
2. "He went to the store already, but forgot to buy the milk."
3. "Aiyah, don't need to rush, the bus already gone."

Usage Notes:
1. 'Already' is often placed at the end of a sentence or phrase, emphasizing the completion or prior occurrence of an action.
2. In informal contexts, 'already' may be shortened to "olor" or "odi," both of which retain the same meaning. For example, "He went home odi" or "I finished eating odi."
3. 'Already' can also be used to express impatience, frustration, or annoyance, depending on the context and tone of the speaker. In such cases, it may be emphasized or elongated, for example, "Alr-r-r-ready lah, why you keep asking?"

Additional Information:
1. 'Already' is a versatile term, and its meaning can vary depending on the context, tone, and intonation used.
2. Singlish speakers often use 'already' as a response instead of directly replying to a question, indicating that they have understood or taken action.

Related Words:
1. 'Abit' - Short for 'a bit,' indicating a small quantity or an amount that is not particularly significant.
2. 'Can' - A versatile term used to express agreement, permission, or the ability to perform an action.
3. 'Liao' - Meaning 'already' or 'finished,' this term emphasizes the completion of a task or the occurrence of a certain event.

Word: Ambilla Labu

Pronunciation: ahm - bil-lah lah-boo

Definition: "Ambilla Labu" is a popular Singlish phrase that is used to express a sense of disbelief, skepticism or to indicate that something is unlikely or impossible. "Ambilla Labu" is a combination of two Hokkien words; 'ambilla' means 'no way' or 'impossible' and 'labu' means 'pumpkin'. Together, the phrase means 'impossible pumpkin'.

Example:
Person A: "I heard that our school is giving out free iPads to all students tomorrow!"
Person B: "Ambilla labu leh, how can it be true?"

In other words, Person B is saying "There's no way that can be true," or "It's impossible for that to happen."

Overall, "ambilla labu" is an informal and humorous way of expressing doubt or skepticism. It is a common phrase in Singaporean English and Hokkien language.

Definition: A Malay term used to describe a Caucasian or white person, primarily of European descent. It is a slang term commonly used in Singapore, Malaysia, and Brunei. Description:
Title: Ang Pow

Definition: 

Ang pow is a term commonly used in Singapore and Malaysia to refer to a traditional gift of money given during special occasions, particularly during Chinese New Year, weddings, and other celebratory events. Derived from Hokkien (a Chinese dialect), it literally translates to "red packet" or "red envelope" in English.

Pronunciation: /ahng-pau/  (pronounced as "ahng" rhymes with "long," "pau" rhymes with "cow")

Alternate Spellings: 

In English, ang pow is the most commonly used spelling. However, due to its origins in the Hokkien dialect, there are a few alternate spellings that reflect the pronunciation in that dialect:

1. Angpao
2. Angpow

Usage Examples:

1. "During Chinese New Year, children receive ang pows from their elders as a symbol of good luck and blessings for the year ahead."

2. "Make sure to prepare enough angpaos for your wedding guests to show your appreciation for their presence on your special day."

3. "I received a generous ang pow from my aunt this year. It will definitely help with my savings!"

4. "The amount of money given in an angpao can vary depending on the relationship between the giver and receiver."

5. "Don't forget to decorate the ang pow envelopes with auspicious symbols and designs."

Additional Information:

Ang pows are usually presented in red envelopes, which symbolize good luck and ward off evil spirits in Chinese culture. Traditionally, the ang pow contains an even amount of money, as odd numbers are associated with funerals and are considered bad luck.

In recent years, ang pows have evolved to include various designs, themes, and even electronic versions in the form of digital transfers. However, the significance of this traditional gift remains intact as a symbol of good wishes, blessings, and financial prosperity.
Description(Final): Ang pow is a term commonly used in Singapore and Malaysia to refer to a traditional gift of money given during special occasions, particularly during Chinese New Year, weddings, and other celebratory events. Derived from Hokkien (a Chinese dialect), it literally translates to "red packet" or "red envelope" in English.
Example(Final):
"Make sure to prepare enough angpaos for your wedding guests to show your appreciation for their presence on your special day."
"The amount of money given in an angpao can vary depending on the relationship between the giver and receiver."

Word: Angmoh

Pronunciation: ang-moh (/æŋmoʊ/)

Alternate spellings: Ang moh, Ang mo, ang mo

Definition:
Angmoh is a colloquial term commonly used in Singapore and Malaysia to refer to people of Caucasian or Western descent. The word originates from the Hokkien dialect, where "ang" means "red" or "western," and "moh" refers to "hair" or "people". 

In Singapore, 'angmoh' is used both as a noun to describe a person and as an adjective to describe anything associated with the Western culture or Caucasians. It can be used in a neutral or even affectionate manner, without necessarily being derogatory or offensive. However, the connotation and intent behind its usage may vary depending on the context and tone of the conversation.

1. "Hey, have you met the new angmoh neighbor? He's from England!"
2. "She bought this angmoh dress for her birthday party."
3. "Angmoh language is so difficult, lah!"
4. "Don't be so angmoh, just join in the local customs and have fun."

Note:
While 'angmoh' is commonly used and understood in Singapore and Malaysia, it is essential to be mindful of the context and sensitivity when using it. It is always best to treat individuals with respect, irrespective of their ethnicity or cultural background.

Definition:
Anot is a contraction of the phrase "is it not" and is commonly used in Singlish, a colloquial form of English spoken in Singapore. It is used as a question tag at the end of a statement to seek confirmation or agreement from the listener.

Example 1:
Statement: "The food at the hawker center is very tasty, anot?"
Translation: "The food at the food court is very tasty, isn't it?"

Example 2:
Statement: "You excited for the concert later, anot?"
Translation: "Are you excited for the concert later?"

Note: "Anot" can also be used as a standalone phrase to ask for agreement or confirmation. It is often used in informal conversations among friends or family members.

Dictionary Entry: 

Anyhow Whack 

Pronunciation: /ˌɛniˈhaʊ wæk/ 

Definition: 

Anyhow Whack is a Singaporean colloquial expression that means to do something without much thought or care, or to go about doing something haphazardly. The phrase implies a lack of proper planning or execution in whatever activity is being done. It can be used to describe someone who is careless or irresponsible in the way they go about doing things. This phrase is often used in Singlish to express a sense of discontent or disapproval towards such behaviour.

Description:
Assam laksa (ah-suhm lah-ksuh) is a popular noodle dish commonly found in Malaysia and Singapore. The dish is made up of rice noodles that are served in a sour and slightly spicy fish broth, that's typically made with tamarind, chili, and various herbs. It is topped with finely sliced cucumber, onion, pineapple, and mint leaves, and often served with a dollop of shrimp paste.

Assam laksa is a flavorful and tangy dish that is enjoyed by many in Southeast Asia. The word 'assam' refers to the sour flavor that's prominent in the dish, while 'laksa' is the type of noodle used. This dish has become a staple of the local food culture in Singapore, and is commonly found in hawker centers, food courts, and restaurants.

Overall, assam laksa is a must-try dish for anyone who enjoys bold and spicy flavors, and wants to experience the taste of authentic Southeast Asian cuisine.

Description:
Assam Pedas (ah-suhm pay-dahs) is a spicy and sour dish commonly found in Malaysian and Singaporean cuisine. The dish usually consists of fish or seafood that is cooked in a tangy tamarind-based broth along with various herbs and spices, including chili peppers, shallots, ginger, garlic, and lemongrass. Other ingredients such as tomatoes and pineapple may also be added for sweetness and extra tang.

Assam Pedas has a unique taste that is both sour and spicy, making it perfect for those who enjoy bold flavors. The sourness comes from the tamarind and is balanced by the heat from the chili peppers. The dish is typically served with rice or noodles and is a popular choice for lunch or dinner.

In Singlish, Assam Pedas is pronounced as "ah-suhm pay-dahs."

- A term used in Singapore to address an older woman or one who appears to be of a similar age or generation to one's own parents. 
- It is used as a sign of respect, similar to 'ma'am' or 'madam'. 
- Additionally, it can also refer to women who work as assistants in a coffee shop or hawker center.

**Pronunciation:** 

/aʊn tiː/

**Example Usage:**

1. "Excuse me, auntie, do you know where the nearest MRT station is?" 
2. "Auntie, can I order a cup of kopi siu dai?"

Description:
Sure, here's the definition of "ayam percik":

Ayam percik (a-yam per-chik) is a popular Malay grilled chicken dish that is marinated in a flavorful blend of spices and coconut milk before being grilled over an open flame. The dish is typically served with a creamy, slightly sweet peanut sauce and steamed rice.

The word "ayam" means chicken in Malay, while "percik" can be roughly translated as splash or drizzle. It is likely named as such due to the way the marinade is splashed or drizzled onto the chicken during the grilling process, giving it a smoky, charred flavor.

Overall, ayam percik is a beloved dish in Malaysia and can often be found at street food vendors and night markets. It is a must-try for those visiting the country or looking to experience a taste of authentic Malay cuisine.

Pronunciation: /aɪ/

Meaning:
1. Interjection: An expression used to convey agreement, affirmation, or consent. It is commonly used in Singaporean English as a colloquial and informal way of saying "yes". 

2. Interjection: An exclamation of mild frustration, disappointment, or resignation. It is commonly used to express annoyance or irritation towards a situation.

3. Noun: A shortened form of "Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation", an international forum that promotes economic cooperation among countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

1. "Hey, wanna grab dinner tonight?" - "Aye, sure! Where should we go?"

2. "Aye, I forgot to bring my umbrella again. Now it's pouring outside!"

Note: The word 'aye' is often pronounced with a rising tone, emphasizing the 'a' sound. The alternative spelling 'aiya' is sometimes used to convey frustration or exasperation with a slightly different nuance.

Example(Final): Going by AYE is the fastest way to get to the college.

Description:
Dictionary Entry: Bak Ku Teh

Word: Bak Ku Teh / Bah Ku Teh
Pronunciation: /bah-koo-teh/

Alternative Spellings: Bah Kut Teh

Definition:
Bak Ku Teh, also known as Bah Ku Teh, is a popular dish in Singaporean and Malaysian cuisine. The term "Bak Ku Teh" roughly translates to "meat bone tea" in English. It is a flavorful and aromatic soup that consists of pork ribs simmered in a mix of herbs, spices, and various medicinal ingredients. The dish is often served with a side of rice or noodles.

Usage:
1. "Let's go for a hearty bowl of Bak Ku Teh for lunch."
2. "Where can I find the best Bak Ku Teh in town?"

Origin:
Bak Ku Teh has its origins in the Hokkien dialect, spoken by the Chinese community in Singapore and Malaysia. "Bak" refers to meat, "Ku" means bone, and "Teh" refers to tea. The name implies that the soup is brewed like tea and contains various meat and bone components, which infuse the broth with a rich and complex flavor.

Cultural Significance:
Bak Ku Teh has become a beloved dish in Singapore and Malaysia, with numerous stalls, eateries, and restaurants specializing in its preparation. It is often enjoyed as a comforting meal, especially during cooler months. The dish is renowned for its herbal infusion, tender pork ribs, and the harmony of flavors produced when the spiced broth is paired with side dishes like braised tofu, mushrooms, and vegetables.

Note:
Due to its popularity, Bak Ku Teh is also sometimes known as "Hainanese Bak Ku Teh" or "Teochew Bak Ku Teh," as different dialect groups have added their own variations to the recipe over time.

Description:
Title: Bang

Definition:
In Singlish, the term "bang" is an onomatopoeic word used to describe a loud noise or a sudden impact. It is commonly used to convey the intense sound created by an explosion, collision, or a forceful action.

Pronunciation: 
/bæŋ/ (bang)

Alternate Spellings: 
None

Example Sentences:
1. "Did you hear that loud bang? I think something crashed outside."
2. "The fireworks display ended with a bang, stunning everyone attending the event."
3. "I accidentally bumped into the table, and it made a loud bang."

Usage Notes:
- The term "bang" is typically associated with describing loud and sudden noises caused by various activities or events.
- It is essential to consider the context in which "bang" is used, as it can refer to both actual sounds and figurative situations.
- This term can be used as both a noun and a verb in Singlish conversations. For example, "There was a loud bang when the door closed" (noun usage), or "He banged the door shut angrily" (verb usage).

Related Terms:
1. Boom: Refers to a loud, deep sound associated with an explosion or a resonating impact, sometimes used interchangeably with "bang" in Singlish.
2. Clang: Describes a loud, metallic sound produced by the collision of objects, similar in context to "bang."
3. Kapow: A playful term used to mimic a sound effect, commonly used in comics or cartoons to describe a sudden explosion or impact.

Note: Singlish, short for Singapore English, is a colloquial form of English widely spoken in Singapore. It incorporates words and phrases from various languages spoken in Singapore, including Malay, Mandarin Chinese, and Tamil, among others.
Description(Final): see 'abang'

Definition:
Bangla is a term commonly used in Singapore to refer to the Bengali community and the language spoken by them. The Bengali community in Singapore hails from Bangladesh and the Indian state of West Bengal. Bangla is an Indo-Aryan language with its roots in the Brahmi script, and it is the seventh most spoken language in the world.

Description:
Title: Bantal Busuk

Pronunciation: BAHN-tahl BOO-sook

Alternate spellings: Bantal Busok

Definition:
Bantal busuk is a Malay term widely used in Singapore and Malaysia, primarily in the Singlish dialect. The term 'bantal' means pillow, while 'busuk' translates to smelly or foul. When combined, 'bantal busuk' refers to a pillow that emits an unpleasant odor. However, within Singlish, the term has evolved to encompass a deeper meaning beyond its literal translation.

Usage:
1. My bantal busuk still smells even after washing it several times.
2. Don't forget to air out your bantal busuk regularly to prevent it from smelling worse.
3. My roommate's bantal busuk is so bad that it can clear a room.

Explanation:
The phrase 'bantal busuk' is often used humorously or affectionately to describe a well-loved or worn-out pillow, despite its odor. It has become a term of endearment or nostalgia, symbolizing comfort or familiarity to some individuals. The phrase holds a sentimental value, especially when referring to a pillow that has been used for many years, despite the unpleasant smell.

However, it is important to note that 'bantal busuk' can be subjective, and what one person finds unpleasant, another may not. Therefore, the term can also be used to describe anything that has a lingering, undesirable smell or an item that evokes nostalgia despite being visually unattractive.

Please note that 'bantal busuk,' being a term from the Singlish dialect, may not be widely understood outside of Singapore and Malaysia, where English is primarily spoken.
Description(Final): lit. smelly pillow. Refers to a small comfort pillow that children hug or carry to sleep (same as chou chou).
Example(Final): 1. The baby cannot sleep without his bantal busuk.

Description:
bao toh (pronounced "bow-toh", alternate spelling: bao-tow) is a Singlish term derived from Hokkien dialect, commonly used in Singapore. It is a slang term that refers to the act of "being caught in the act" or getting exposed for something that one had intended to keep hidden or secret.

The term "bao toh" is often used to describe situations where someone's secretive or mischievous behavior is uncovered, resulting in embarrassment or shame. It can be used in various contexts, such as when someone is caught cheating in a game, being caught in a lie, or getting caught doing something sneaky.

Example:

1. "Don't try to cheat during the exam, or you might bao toh!"
2. "He thought he could get away with taking extra snacks from the pantry, but he got bao toh by the boss."

Overall, "bao toh" carries a connotation of being exposed or getting into trouble due to one's own actions. It is a fun and expressive Singlish term that adds color to conversations.
Description(Final): (Wiktionary) From Hokkien 包刀 (pau-to, “wrapped knife”), referring to backstabbing. To inform on someone behind his or her back.
Example(Final): Don't tell him what you're doing. He confirm bao toh you.

- A versatile Singlish term used to express a wide range of emotions, from shock and disbelief to frustration and anger.

- "Basket sia, I cannot believe he did that!" (expresses shock or disbelief)

Description:
Title: Bee hoon

Pronunciation: Bee hoon (bee-hoon)

Alternate Spellings: Beehoon, bhi hoon, bihun (used in Malaysia)

Definition:
Bee hoon is a popular term in Singlish and refers to a type of thin rice noodles commonly used in a variety of traditional Singaporean and Asian dishes. The term 'bee hoon' is derived from the Hokkien dialect, which is widely spoken in Singapore. It is often spelled as one word: Beehoon.

Usage:
1. Did you try the mee goreng with bee hoon at the hawker center? It's delicious!
2. I'm craving for some bee hoon soup for dinner tonight.
3. Let's make a stir-fry with bee hoon and vegetables.

Explanation:
Bee hoon, also known as rice vermicelli, is made from rice flour, water, and sometimes starch. It has a translucent appearance and a delicate texture. This noodle variety comes in different thicknesses, such as thin, medium, and thick bee hoon. Bee hoon is often soaked in water before being cooked and is used in a wide range of dishes, including fried bee hoon, bee hoon soup, bee hoon soto, and bee hoon stir-fry.

In Singaporean cuisine, bee hoon is a versatile ingredient and is commonly found in popular local dishes like Singapore-style fried bee hoon, which is stir-fried with various vegetables, thinly sliced meat, and often seasoned with soy sauce or curry powder. It is also commonly used in laksa, a spicy noodle soup, where the bee hoon soaks up the rich and fragrant coconut-based broth.

In Malaysian cuisine, particularly in Malay, Chinese, and Nyonya cuisines, bee hoon is equally treasured and used in dishes like bihun goreng (fried bee hoon), bee hoon soup, and soto bihun (bee hoon soup with spices).

Overall, bee hoon is an essential ingredient in Singaporean and Malaysian culinary traditions, and its delectable taste and versatility have made it a beloved staple in many local dishes.
Description(Final): see 'beehoon'

Belacan (pronounced be-LAH-chun) is a type of fermented shrimp paste commonly used in Southeast Asian cuisine, particularly in Malaysian and Indonesian dishes. It is made from grinding up small shrimp and then fermenting them with salt for several weeks, until the mixture becomes a thick paste with a very strong, pungent aroma. 

Belacan is a staple ingredient in dishes like sambal belacan (a spicy chili paste), asam pedas (a sour and spicy fish stew), and kangkung belacan (water spinach stir-fried with belacan and chili). A little bit goes a long way in terms of adding umami and depth to dishes, but it's definitely not for the faint of heart!

"Be careful not to inhale too deeply when using belacan in the kitchen - the smell can be quite overpowering!"

Description:
Belachan (pronounced buh-lah-chan) is a Malay loanword commonly used in Singlish. It refers to a pungent shrimp paste that is widely used in Southeast Asian cuisine, particularly in dishes from Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia.

Alternate Spellings: Blachan, belacan

Belachan is made from fermented ground shrimp mixed with salt and is typically sun-dried into small blocks or thick sheets. It has a distinctive aroma and adds a depth of flavor to various traditional dishes, such as sambal belachan, which is a popular chili paste, and laksa, a spicy noodle soup.

The usage of belachan in Singlish is not limited to just culinary descriptions. It is often used metaphorically to describe someone or something with a strong and overpowering presence. For example, one might say, "He's like belachan, always making himself the center of attention."

In Singlish, it is not uncommon to hear individuals pronouncing the word as "bel-chan" or "bela-chaan." However, the correct pronunciation follows the Malay pronunciation mentioned earlier.

Overall, belachan is an essential ingredient in Southeast Asian cooking and has made its way into Singlish vocabulary to depict both its culinary and metaphorical characteristics.

Description:
Title: Bell Curve God

Definition:
Bell Curve God is a colloquial term commonly used in Singapore to describe an individual who consistently achieves exceptionally high grades or ranks at the top of an academic curve, especially in a competitive or demanding subject. This term is derived from the concept of a bell curve, a statistical curve used to represent the distribution of grades or scores in a class.

Pronunciation: [bel kerv gawd]

Alternate Spellings: -
There are no official alternate spellings for this term.

Usage:
- "Wow, Jenny is such a Bell Curve God! She keeps getting perfect scores in every math test!"
- "You can always count on Mark to ace his exams, he's the Bell Curve God of our class!"

Characteristics:
1. High Achiever: A Bell Curve God stands out among their peers as they consistently excel academically.

4. Statistical Awareness: They are aware of the concept of bell curves and understand how grade distributions work in a class.

Connotation:
The term Bell Curve God is mostly used in a positive or admiration-filled context. While there may be an element of envy or competitiveness, it is generally used to recognize someone's outstanding academic abilities rather than belittle their achievements.

Note:
In Singlish, the term Bell Curve God is used playfully or jokingly to describe individuals who consistently excel academically. It does not hold any religious significance and should be understood in its colloquial context.

Title: Bioscope

Word: Bioscope 
Pronunciation: /bai-uh-skohp/
Alternate spellings: Biaskop, Biaskope

Definition:
Bioscope refers to a term commonly used in Singapore, derived from the word "bioscope," which originated from the early days of cinema. This Singlish term typically refers to a movie theater or a cinema hall.

Example sentences:
1. "Let's catch a movie at the bioscope tomorrow, there's a new blockbuster I really want to watch!"
2. "The latest film at the bioscope is getting rave reviews; we should definitely check it out."

Usage notes:
The term "bioscope" is an informal expression commonly used by Singaporeans to refer to a movie theater. It may not be frequently used in formal or official settings.

Origins:
The term "bioscope" was derived from a short-lived and early motion-picture projector called the Bioscope, which was popular in the early 20th century. Although the projector itself is no longer in use, the term has survived and is used colloquially to refer to movie theaters in Singapore.

Additional information:
In Singaporean English, the term "bioscope" is widely understood but may not be as commonly used as "cinema" or "movie theater" in day-to-day conversation. It showcases the unique linguistic blend found in the Singlish dialect, a mixture of English, Malay, Hokkien, Tamil, and other local languages.

Dictionary Entry: Birthday Noodle

Pronunciation: /bərθ-deɪ ˈnuːd(ə)l/

Alternate Spellings: None

Definition:
Birthday Noodle refers to a specific type of noodle dish commonly consumed in Singapore and other parts of Asia to celebrate one's birthday. This dish is prepared by stir-frying yellow noodles along with an assortment of ingredients such as sliced chicken, shrimp, fish cake, vegetables, and occasionally pork or beef. The noodles are symbolic of longevity and are often cooked until they become slightly crispy to represent a wish for a long and healthy life.

In Singlish, the term "birthday noodle" may be used interchangeably with "longevity noodles" or simply "birthday mee" (pronounced /miː/), as the word "mee" is a colloquial term for noodles in Singapore.

Example Usage:
Andy: "Hey, my grandma's birthday is coming up. Let's cook her some birthday noodle!"
Yan: "That's a great idea! It's a meaningful way to celebrate her birthday and wish her good health."

Note:
In local Chinese culture, birthday noodle is often served during birthday celebrations, as it is believed to bring good luck and blessings for the person celebrating their special day.
Description(Final): (Wiktionary) A Chinese yi mein noodle of a kind eaten on birthdays to celebrate a long life.
Example(Final): Remember to order some birthday noodle for your grandma's birthday this weekend.

Description:
Title: BJ

Pronunciation: bee-jay

Alternate Spellings: Beng Jialat, Bo Jio

Definition: 

BJ is an abbreviation commonly used in Singlish to refer to the act of being left out or being excluded from an event or activity. The term "BJ" is derived from the Hokkien dialect, where 'Beng Jialat' literally translates to "very pathetic" or "very miserable." It is often used to express disappointment or frustration when someone feels left out or when they are not invited or informed of a particular gathering, outing, or any other social occasion.

Usage:

1. Hey, why did you BJ me from the chalet last weekend? I would have loved to join you guys!

2. A: Eh bro, going for supper later, wanna join?
   B: No way, don't BJ me, ask me earlier lah!

3. Sheila: What? I can't believe you BJ-ed me from the party!
   Kevin: Sorry lah, it was a last-minute plan.

4. Amanda: I hope they don't BJ us from the surprise farewell party.
   Dennis: Yeah, I really want to say goodbye to our colleague.

Note: It is important to acknowledge that the term "BJ" is often used informally and may not be suitable for formal contexts.

Word: Blur like sotong

Pronunciation: /bləː laɪk ˈsɒtɒŋ/

Definition: An idiomatic expression commonly used in Singapore's English language or Singlish. It means to be extremely confused, disoriented or clueless about a certain situation or task. 

Example:

Person A: "Eh, you know where Uncle Lim's store is located ah?"

Person B: "Sorry lah, I blur like sotong leh. No idea."

Origin: 'Blur' means confused or hazy and 'sotong' means squid in Malay language. In this context, the idiom 'blur like sotong' suggests that the person who is confused is as disoriented as a squid, which is likely to be in a haze or confused state, especially when caught in a fishing net.

Note: This idiom is commonly used in Singapore and Malaysia, and may not be familiar to those from other countries.

Entry: BMT

Pronunciation: /bee-em-tee/

Alternate Spellings: Basic Military Training

Definition:
BMT, short for Basic Military Training, is an acronym commonly used in Singapore to refer to the initial training program that individuals undergo upon enlisting in the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF). It is a rigorous and structured program designed to instill discipline, physical fitness, and military skills in recruits.

In a broader context, 'BMT' can also be used to describe the overall experience of undergoing basic military training, including the challenges, routines, and camaraderie formed during this period.

Example Usage:
1. "I just completed my BMT, and I feel stronger and more disciplined than ever!"
2. "During BMT, we had to wake up early for physical training every morning."
3. "BMT buddies often develop lifelong friendships through shared hardships and experiences."

Note: 'BMT' is widely understood as an abbreviation for Basic Military Training in Singapore, and its usage is specific to conversations related to the SAF.

Sure, here's an entry for 'bo':

Bo (pronounced as "boh" with a short "o" sound)

1. Description: Bo is a ubiquitous Singlish particle that is commonly used to indicate a negative response or to negate a statement. It is equivalent to the English word "no" or "not". Bo is often used at the end of a sentence or clause, and can be used alone or in combination with other particles such as "lah" or "leh".

2. Example usage:
- "You going to the party later?" "Bo lah, I have to study for exams"
- "Did you see the new Avengers movie?" "Bo, I had to work late"

3. Variations:
- "Bo jio" is a common expression used to express disappointment in not being invited to an event or outing. It translates to "did not invite".
- "Bo hua" is used to describe someone who is unlucky or having bad luck.

Description:
Word: Bo Bian

Pronunciation: boh bee-an

Alternate Spellings: Bo pian, Boh bian

Definition:

Bo bian is a popular Singlish phrase used to express a situation where one has no choice or alternative but to accept a specific outcome, regardless of personal preference or desire. It highlights the resignation or acceptance of a circumstance that is beyond one's control.

Example:

1. "I want to stay longer at the party, but my parents want me home early, so bo bian lah, I have to leave."

2. "I don't really enjoy eating vegetables, but if I want to stay healthy, bo bian, I have to eat them."

3. "The bus is always crowded during peak hours, so bo bian, I have to squeeze in and stand."

Usage Notes:

- Bo bian is commonly used in casual conversations among Singaporeans to convey a sense of inevitability or helplessness in accepting a situation.
- It can be used as a standalone phrase or in combination with other words or phrases to enhance its meaning.
- It is often accompanied by hand gestures or facial expressions to emphasize the lack of choice or alternative.

Related Terms:

- Sian: Refers to a feeling of boredom, weariness, or frustration, often used in conjunction with bo bian to express a sense of resignation or annoyance.
- Jia lat: Another Singlish phrase used to describe a difficult or problematic situation, often used interchangeably with bo bian to convey a similar sense of helplessness.

Note: Singlish is a colloquial language unique to Singapore, blending elements of English, Malay, Hokkien, Cantonese, and other local languages and dialects. It is primarily spoken and may not conform to standard English grammar rules.
Description(Final): Bo bian is a phrase used to express that one has no choice or alternative but to accept a specific outcome, regardless of personal preference or desire. It highlights the resignation or acceptance of a circumstance that is beyond one's control.

Description:
Title: Bo Jio

Pronunciation: boh-jee-oh

Alternate Spellings: bo jiak, bojio

Meaning:
Bo jio is a commonly used Singlish phrase that conveys a sense of disappointment or annoyance when someone fails to invite or inform another person about an enjoyable activity or event. It is an expression of being left out or feeling excluded, and signifies the absence of an invitation. The phrase is often used in a lighthearted or playful manner among friends, and it can evoke a slightly teasing or humorous tone.

Usage:
1. I can't believe you went to the beach without me, bo jio!
2. Why did you eat at that fancy restaurant and not invite us? Bo jiak!
3. Next time, don't bo jio me for the movie night, okay?

Example:
Amy: "Hey, did you go to the party at John's house last weekend?"
Ben: "No lah! Bo jio sia! Why didn't you tell me?"

Note: 'Bo jio' is derived from the Hokkien dialect in Singapore, which translates to "no invite". The phrase has become incorporated into Singlish, which is a unique blend of English, Malay, Mandarin, and other local languages spoken in Singapore.
Description(Final): To leave someone out from an event or activity by not inviting them. (Wiktionary)
Example(Final):
Amy: "Hey, did you go to the party at John's house last weekend?"
Ben: "No lah! Bo jio sia! Why didn't you tell me?"

Description:
Title: Bodoh

Pronunciation: boh-doh

Alternate Spellings: Bodoh (Standard Singapore English)

Definition:
Bodoh is a colloquial term widely used in Singaporean Singlish. It is derived from the Malay language, commonly spoken by the Malay community in Singapore. The word 'bodoh' is typically used to describe someone or something that is foolish, unintelligent, or lacking common sense. It is often employed in a lighthearted or affectionate manner among friends, but can also carry a derogatory undertone depending on the context.

Example Usage:
1. Don't be so bodoh lah, I already explained it to you!
2. Wah, you really bodoh sia! How could you forget your own birthday?

Etymology:
The word 'bodoh' originated from the Malay language, where it carries the exact same meaning. It has since been assimilated into Singlish due to the influence of the Malay community on Singapore's linguistic landscape. The word has become an integral part of Singlish vocabulary, used by locals of all ethnic backgrounds.

Cultural Significance:
'Bodoh' is not only a linguistic expression but also reflects the unique cultural and linguistic diversity of Singapore. Its usage has created a shared understanding and bond among Singaporeans, regardless of their ethnic backgrounds. However, it is essential to use the term with sensitivity, making sure not to offend or upset others unintentionally.

Related Terms:
1. Blur: Similar to 'bodoh,' this term is used to describe someone who is absent-minded or easily confused.
2. Sotong: Derived from the Malay word for squid, this term is used to describe someone who is clueless or has a tendency to make mistakes.

Note: While Singlish is an essential part of Singaporean colloquial communication, it is important to adapt the register according to the situation when interacting with non-Singaporeans or in formal settings.

Description:
Word: BTO

Pronunciation: bi-tee-oh

Definition: BTO stands for "Build-To-Order" and is a government housing policy in Singapore. It refers to new public housing flats that are built by the Housing and Development Board (HDB) in response to demand. Under the BTO system, individuals or couples can apply for a new HDB flat before it is constructed. Successful applicants are then able to select their preferred unit and location from the available options.

Alternate spellings:
- B.T.O.
- bto

Word: BTO flat 

Pronunciation: B-T-O flat 

Alternate spellings: None 

Definition: 

- A BTO flat, also known as Build-To-Order flat, refers to a type of public housing in Singapore that is built in response to demand. It is a subsidized housing option offered by the Housing and Development Board (HDB) to eligible Singaporeans. 

- BTO flats are purpose-built residential units planned and constructed by the HDB based on the number of applications received in specific housing projects. These flats are usually located in new housing estates or existing ones undergoing redevelopment. 
   
- BTO flats are sold directly by the HDB through scheduled sales exercises, where interested applicants can apply for their preferred flat type and location. These exercises are generally held a few times a year. Successful applicants are then chosen through a computerized balloting system.

- BTO flats are popular among young couples or families aspiring to own their first home, as they offer affordable and newly built housing options. They come in various sizes and designs, ranging from studio apartments to larger multi-room units.

Example usage: 

1. "My husband and I just got married, so we're planning to apply for a BTO flat next year."

2. "The BTO flat we applied for is in a convenient location with good amenities nearby."

3. "Did you hear about the recent BTO flat launch? The queue was crazy!"

Note: Singlish is an English-based creole language spoken in Singapore. While Singlish borrows words from various languages, including Malay, Chinese, and Tamil, the term BTO flat remains the same in Singlish as it is derived from English and widely used in the local context.

buay song (pronounced "bwu-sorng"; alternate spelling "boh song") - a Singlish phrase meaning "not happy" or "unhappy". It is often used to express dissatisfaction with a situation or to describe a feeling of discomfort or annoyance. Example: "Eh, this food very salty leh, I buay song sia".

The word "buay" comes from the Hokkien dialect and means "cannot" or "not able to". "Song" comes from the Mandarin word "shàng" (上) which means "up" or "above". Together, "buay song" conveys the feeling of being unable to rise above a situation, hence the expression of unhappiness.

Overall, "buay song" is a commonly used and well-understood Singlish phrase that reflects the unique linguistic and cultural background of Singapore.

Description:
Sure, here's the dictionary entry for "bubor chacha":

Bubor Chacha (pronunciation: boo-baw cha-cha; alternate spellings: bubur cha cha) is a classic dessert dish commonly found in Singapore and Malaysia. It is a sweet, creamy, and fragrant dessert made from a mixture of coconut milk, palm sugar, and pandan leaves. The ingredients are then boiled together with taro root, sweet potatoes, and sometimes yam (also known as "orh" in Hokkien) until the mixture turns into a thick and creamy pudding-like consistency.

The word "bubor" in Malay means porridge, while "chacha" is likely a Chinese Hokkien word for the root vegetables used in the dish. It is often served warm or chilled and can be enjoyed as a dessert or a snack. Some variants may also include sago pearls or durian for an added flavor.

Example: "I can't wait to have a bowl of bubor chacha after dinner tonight!"

Note: Singlish is an informal language that incorporates words and phrases from various languages spoken in Singapore such as Malay, Mandarin, Hokkien and Tamil, among others. Hence, Singlish words often vary in spellings and pronunciations.
Description(Final): Bubor Chacha is a classic dessert dish commonly found in Singapore and Malaysia. It is a sweet, creamy, and fragrant dessert made from a mixture of coconut milk, palm sugar, and pandan leaves. It is often served warm or chilled and can be enjoyed as a dessert or a snack. Some variants may also include sago pearls or durian for an added flavor.

Description:
Title: Build-to-Order

Definition:
Build-to-Order (BTO) refers to a housing scheme in Singapore where new public housing flats are built based on demand, allowing interested buyers to apply for these flats during specific application exercises. Under this scheme, buyers have the opportunity to select the location, flat type, and other desired specifications before the construction of the flats begins.

Pronunciation: bild-tuh-aw-duh

Alternate Spellings: BTO

Example:
John and Mary decided to apply for a build-to-order flat in the upcoming exercise as they wanted to have a say in customizing their future home.

Usage:
1. I heard that the new build-to-order flats in Punggol are selling out fast!
2. The government's build-to-order scheme aims to provide affordable housing options to Singaporeans.

Note: The term "build-to-order" is commonly abbreviated to "BTO" in conversations and written communication for brevity.

Description:
Entry: Buka Puasa

Pronunciation: boo-kah poo-ah-sah

Alternate spellings: Bukka Puasa

Definition:
Buka Puasa is a term commonly used in Singapore to refer to the act of breaking one's fast during the Islamic holy month of Ramadan. It specifically describes the moment when Muslims partake in their first meal after abstaining from food and drink from dawn till dusk. This term is predominantly used within the Malay-Muslim community and is also widely understood among other ethnic groups in Singapore.

Example:

1. "Let's gather at the mosque for buka puasa. We can enjoy a wholesome meal together after a day of fasting."

2. "During Ramadan, we join our Muslim friends for buka puasa feasts where we can experience the spirit of togetherness and celebration."

Usage notes:
Buka Puasa is often associated with a sense of communal unity and is viewed as a special time for worship and reflection. It is also a significant occasion where families and friends come together to break their fast and share a meal. In Singapore, many restaurants and food establishments offer special buka puasa menus during Ramadan, catering to both the Muslim community and those who wish to experience the traditional culinary delights associated with this occasion.

Word: Cafe Hop

Pronunciation: /keh-f-hop/

Alternate Spelling(s): None

Definition:

1. Verb phrase: To engage in the activity of visiting multiple cafes in a row, typically in search of unique or trending food and drink experiences. Cafe hopping is popular among Singaporeans and is often seen as a social and recreational activity.

Example 1:
Joanna and her friends decided to cafe hop around the city, trying out different coffee blends and pastries.

Example 2:
After a tiring week at work, David planned to de-stress by cafe hopping and trying some new artisanal teas.

Usage note:
The term "cafe hop" is widely used in Singlish, indicating the act of exploring various cafes. It is often used in casual conversation among friends or when discussing weekend plans.

Related terms:

2. Hipster cafes - (noun) A trendy category of cafes, known for their unique ambiance, innovative menus, and artistic decor.

Caution:
Although cafe hopping can be an enjoyable experience, it is important to practice responsible consumption and adhere to individual budgetary constraints. Remember to drink and eat in moderation, and be mindful of the environment and fellow cafe-goers.

Title: Cafe-Hopping

Pronunciation: kah-f-hop-ing

Alternate Spellings: Cafehopping

Cafe-hopping is a term commonly used in Singlish to refer to the act of visiting multiple cafes in a single outing. It involves exploring various coffee shops and cafes, often in different locations, with the intention of experiencing their unique atmospheres, trying out different food and drink options, and enjoying the overall cafe culture. This activity is particularly popular among young locals and tourists seeking to indulge in a leisurely and social coffee-drinking experience.

Example:
Jane: "Hey, want to go cafe-hopping this weekend? I heard there are some great new coffee spots in town."
John: "Sure! I'm always up for exploring new cafes and trying different types of coffee."

Note: 'Cafe-hopping' is often used as a standalone term without alteration, as it accurately reflects the concept of visiting multiple cafes in a single outing.

Sure, here's the dictionary entry for "cake lapis":

Word: Cake Lapis
Pronunciation: kek LAH-pis
Alternate spellings: Kueh lapis, kuih lapis

Definition:
Cake lapis is a traditional, layered cake that is popular in Southeast Asian countries like Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore. "Cake lapis" literally translates to "layered cake" in Indonesian and Malay. The cake is made by layering thin sheets of multicolored batter one on top of the other, with each layer being baked and cooled before the next one is added. The result is a cake with a striking, multicolored pattern when cut into slices. Cake lapis can come in various flavors such as vanilla, chocolate, pandan, and even durian!

Example:
"I brought some cake lapis to share with you guys. It's my grandma's recipe and it's always a crowd-pleaser!"

Title: Calefare

Pronunciation: kah-luh-fair

Alternate Spellings: Kalefare, calafare

Description:
Calefare is a Singlish term originating from the combination of the words 'calendar' and 'fare'. It refers to an individual who takes on minor or unimportant roles as an extra in local film or television productions. The term is commonly used in the entertainment industry in Singapore.

The calefare's role often involves appearing in the background of scenes, without any significant dialogue or storyline involvement. These roles are usually non-speaking or may have minimal lines to deliver. Calefares are not considered main characters or lead actors but are valuable in adding depth and authenticity to a production’s setting or atmosphere. 

In a broader context, the term 'calefare' can also be used to describe anyone who is seen as insignificant or unimportant in a particular situation.

Example Sentences:
1. "I managed to get a gig as a calefare in the latest local drama series."
2. "Our school is looking for calefares to take part in a historical reenactment scene for a documentary."
3. "Although he had a calefare role, it was his first step in the acting industry."

Note: The term 'calefare' has its roots in Singlish, the colloquial fusion of English, Malay, Chinese dialects, and other local languages commonly spoken in Singapore. It may not be familiar or recognized outside of Singapore.

Description:
Can die is a commonly used Singlish phrase that expresses extreme emotion, usually to emphasize extreme joy or surprise, as if one is about to die from happiness or shock. It can be pronounced as "can-die" or "cun-die". 

Example:
Person 1: "Hey! You won the lottery!"
Person 2: "OMG, can die sia!" 

In this example, person 2 expresses extreme excitement by exclaiming "can die sia", emphasizing that the news is so great that they are overwhelmed to the point of feeling like they might die.

It is also used in a negative sense, to show great disappointment or frustration.

Example:
Person 1: "Sorry lah, cannot make it for dinner tonight."
Person 2: "Aiyo, can die already lah. Never mind, next time then."

In this example, Person 2 expresses disappointment and frustration at not being able to have dinner with Person 1, even going to the extent of saying "can die already". 

Overall, "can die" is a versatile phrase used to express extreme emotions in Singlish.

Word: Carrot Cake

Definition: A popular Singaporean dish made from stir-fried cubes of radish cake (also known as turnip cake or yam cake) with eggs, preserved radish (chai poh), garlic, and sometimes other ingredients such as prawns or pork. The name "carrot cake" is a direct translation from the Teochew dialect, where "chai tow kway" (菜头粿) means "radish cake". It is commonly served as a breakfast or supper dish.

Description:
carrot cake (noun)

Pronunciation: /ka-roht kek/

Alternate spellings: carrot cake

Definition:
1. In Singaporean English, carrot cake refers to a popular local dish that is not actually made with carrots and cake. It is a type of fried radish cake, also known as "chai tow kway," commonly found in hawker centers and coffee shops across the island.

2. Carrot cake is made by stir-frying squares or strips of steamed radish cake (made from rice flour and shredded radishes) with eggs, garlic, preserved radish, soy sauce, and sometimes chili paste. The mixture is then stir-fried until it has a crispy texture and slightly charred aroma.

Example:
"In Singapore, you must try the carrot cake at the hawker center. It's a unique and delicious dish!"

Origin:
The name "carrot cake" is a misnomer and can be misleading, as the dish does not contain carrots nor is it an actual cake. The name is derived from the translation of "chai tow kway" in Teochew Chinese (one of the local dialects spoken in Singapore) where "chai tow" means radish and "kway" means cake.

Note:
Carrot cake can be served in two different styles, namely "white" and "black." The "white" version consists of radish cake stir-fried with eggs and garlic, while the "black" version includes sweet dark soy sauce, resulting in a darkened appearance.

Description:
Title: Catch No Ball

Definition:
Catch No Ball is a colloquial Singlish phrase commonly used to convey a state of confusion or lack of understanding. It is used to describe moments when someone fails to comprehend a particular situation, concept, or information being communicated to them. The phrase implies that the person is unable to "catch" or grasp the "ball" or point being made, resulting in confusion or bewilderment.

Pronunciation: [kach no bawl]

Alternate Spellings: 
1. Catch Cannot Ball
2. Catch Don't Ball

Example Sentences:
1. "I tried explaining the complex math problem to him, but he still catch no ball."
2. "The teacher's explanation was so unclear, everyone in class catch no ball."
3. "He was speaking too fast in Mandarin, I catch cannot ball what he said."

Usage Notes:
- "Catch No Ball" is typically used in spoken language and informal contexts.
- The phrase is often used in friendly banter or casual conversations to express confusion or acknowledge a lack of understanding.
- It can be used across different situations, such as in academic settings, work environments, or even for casual matters like jokes or gossip.

Cultural Significance:
The use of Singlish phrases like "Catch No Ball" reflects the multicultural and multilingual nature of Singapore, where English is commonly spoken as a first or second language alongside other local languages like Mandarin, Malay, and Tamil. Singlish phrases add a unique flavor to the language landscape of Singapore, embodying the cultural identity and communal spirit of the nation.

Sure, here's a dictionary entry for 'century egg':

Century Egg (noun) - A Chinese delicacy, also known as pidan, preserved duck egg or hundred-year egg.

Pronunciation: sen-chuh-ree egg

Alternate spellings: century eggs, centenary eggs, pidan, preserved duck eggs

Description: Century egg is a type of egg that has been preserved in a mixture of clay, ash, salt, quicklime and rice straw for several weeks to several months, depending on the desired taste and texture. The process of preserving the egg causes the yolk to turn greenish-black and the egg white to become a translucent, jelly-like substance with a strong pungent aroma. Century eggs are commonly eaten as a snack or used as an ingredient in porridge, congee or as a topping for rice dishes.

Sure thing! Here's the dictionary entry for "change parade":

Word: Change parade

Pronunciation: /tʃeɪndʒ pəˈreɪd/

Alternate spellings: Chenge parade

Definition: A process where a customer at a hawker stall selects a food item and requests for specific changes to the dish, such as substituting ingredients or adding extra seasoning. The vendor then announces the changes to the rest of the staff at the stall, who may also repeat the order to ensure accuracy.

Example: "Uncle, can I have the char kway teow with less cockles and more bean sprouts, and can you add extra chilli? Don't forget to tell everyone it's a change parade!"

Note: "Change parade" is a commonly used phrase in Singapore to describe the process of customising a dish at a hawker stall. It is a reflection of the efficient and organised system of hawker culture in Singapore, where vendors work together to fulfil customer orders accurately and quickly.

In Singapore, it refers to the 15th day of the first lunar month, which is also known as the Chinese Valentine's Day. During this day, single women in Singapore would throw mandarin oranges into the river to find their true love. In modern times, the tradition has evolved into throwing oranges into the sea or other water bodies. Description:
Title: Cheebai (chi-bye) - A Singlish Dictionary Entry

Pronunciation: /ʧiːbaɪ/

Alternate Spellings: Cheebye, Chibai, Cheebbaya

Definition:
Cheebai is a widely used vulgar slang term in Singlish, originating from the Hokkien dialect. It is primarily used as a profane and explicit expression to refer to the male genitalia. However, it is also used metaphorically, in a more toned-down manner, to express frustration, annoyance, or disbelief. It is essential to note that the usage of this term is strictly informal, impolite, and should be avoided in formal or professional settings.

Example Usages:
1. "Walao, that cheebai parked his car in the middle of the road lah!"
Translation: "Wow, that idiot parked his car in the middle of the road!"

2. "My cheebai, you never pay me back the money you owe!"
Translation: "You never paid me back the money you owe me!"

3. "Cheebai, the train service breakdown again!"
Translation: "Oh no, the train service has broken down again!"

4. "Eh, don't disturb him. He's damn cheebai angry now."
Translation: "Hey, don't disturb him. He's very angry now."

5. "Macha, you better don't cheebai with me!"
Translation: "Dude, don't mess with me!"

Please exercise caution and sensitivity when using this term, as it is highly vulgar and could be offensive to some people. It is advisable to restrict the use of this term to informal and casual conversations with close friends who understand the context and the nature of such vulgar language in Singlish.

Cher is a Singlish slang term derived from the English word "teacher". It is commonly used by Singaporeans to refer to a school teacher, specifically addressing the person with respect and familiarity. The term is often accompanied by a person's first name or a specific title, such as "Miss Cher" or "Mr. Cher", to show respect towards the teacher.

Example:

Student 2: "Mr. Chur, can you please explain this concept again?"

Note:
The use of "Cher" is considered informal and is typically used among students when addressing their teachers. It is important to note that while it may be accepted within the classroom setting, using this term outside a school environment may not be appropriate or respectful in some cases.

Description:
Title: Chialat (chī-ah-laht)
Alternate Spellings: Jialat, chayalat, jialat

Definition:
Chialat is a Singlish slang term that is commonly used to express extreme dismay, disappointment, or frustration. This versatile term can be used to describe various situations, events, or feelings that are perceived as unfortunate, unfavorable, troublesome, or challenging. Its usage is often accompanied by a humorous tone, lightening the impact of the negative sentiment it conveys.

Examples:
1. "I just missed my bus and it started raining. Chialat lah!" (I missed my bus and, on top of that, it started raining. What a disaster!)

2. "My boss just assigned me another urgent project. Chialat sia!" (My boss just gave me another urgent project. What a nightmare!)

3. "I spilled coffee on my brand new white shirt. Chialat, how to remove this stain?" (I accidentally spilled coffee on my new white shirt. What a mess! How can I get rid of this stain?)

Usage Notes:
- The term "chialat" originates from the Hokkien dialect but is widely used and understood across different languages and dialects in Singapore.
- It is typically used in informal conversations among friends and family, and may not be appropriate in formal or professional settings.
- In certain instances, "jialat" can also describe a challenging or tough scenario, exaggerating the degree of difficulty or the severity of a situation.

Entry: Chinese helicopter

Definition:
Chinese helicopter is a colloquial term used in Singlish to describe a situation where someone tries to avoid or evade responsibility or blame by changing the subject or diverting attention away from the issue at hand. The term is derived from the image of a helicopter rapidly changing directions and hovering above an area, symbolizing the act of avoiding direct confrontation or accountability.

Example sentences:
